Award.AwardTitle: Technical Symposium for Students Underrepresented in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) supports conferences and workshops that seek to increase the research and education capacity of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students and faculty at HBCUs. Morgan State University will organize a student symposium held in conjunction with the 91st National Technical Association (NTA) Annual Conference to be held on September 26-27, 2019 at Coppin State University. Undergraduate students from HBCUs will attend this two-day symposium to present their research and build a network of support by interacting with faculty and industry representatives.

The NTA, established in 1926, promotes the involvement of undergraduate students in scientific and technical research activities. The symposium sessions will provide a culminating experience for students to disseminate research results to peers and professionals attending the NTA conference through oral and poster sessions. Students will have the ability to attend some of the conference panels and presentations, the Career Awareness, Educational and Employment STEAM Opportunities Expo, and the awards presentation. A key objective is to provide undergraduate students the opportunity to network with scientists and engineers from academia, industry, government agencies, and the private sector.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Underrepresented minority and female students had a great conference experience on the campus of Coppin State University during the 91st National Technical Symposium.  Students traveled to Baltimore on Wednesday, September 25, 2019 and left Baltimore on Friday September 27 or Saturday September 28, 2019. All students were able to participate in the full two-and-a-half-day conference with networking, plenary, and professional development sessions, presentations from students and professionals, in addition to a great award ceremony at the end of the conference. 

There were 62 abstracts submitted to the call for abstracts for the Student Symposium and 49 of the students were able to give an oral or poster presentation.  Participants were from 20 institutions of higher educations (IHEs), one federal laboratory, one research center, and one high school. The twenty IHEs are Morgan State University (student symposium organizer), Coppin State University (conference host), North Carolina A&T State University, Florida A&M University, North Carolina Central University, Langston University, Hampton University, Bowie State University, Philander Smith College, University of Maryland Eastern Shore, ECPI University, Notre Dame of Maryland University, Eckerd College, Johns Hopkins University, New Mexico State University, Indiana University, University of Cincinnati, Yale University, Auburn University, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Others are STEM Tech Neighborhood Academy, Marine Research Laboratory (NOAA Woods Hole), and Baltimore Polytechnic Institute.   

Among the 20 IHEs represented, 10 were Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), one Hispanic Serving Institution, six R-1 institutions, and three liberal art colleges. However, 39 of the 49 student presenters (80%) were from HBCUs.  Of the 62 students participated in the conference, 30 were females.  Therefore, we were able t achieve our goal to reach out to underrepresented minority and female students to attend the conference.

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2020
Modified by: Hongtao Yu
